Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a couple having intercourse. The woman is lying on a pillow on her front, head turned to right smiling with short closely curled hair. Most of the man is missing apart from oversized phallus. Mould-made and solid. Traces of white coating, with traces of pink paint on skin, red paint on pillow. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Close parallels, probably from Naukratis, are dated end of the Late Period or Early Ptolemaic (Bailey 2008, no.3265 GR 1973,0501.5, see also style of nos.3214-5, GR 1973,0501.6, GR 1973,0501.24). A very close, but unprovenanced, parallel is published by Dunand as ‘Roman’ (Dunand 1990, no. 625). Similar pose on limestone plaque found at Naukratis (Cairo National Museum JE33557 SR5/6332). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.313) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 95, nos 271-280)
